position.marginalia_text: Nihil tam aduersum Entelechia[e], quàm Venus, et Carcer.

marginalia.translation: Nothing is more adverse to Actualization than Venus and Jail.

position.marginalia_text: Coelebs, quasi coelitum vnus. a[e]thereus vir.

marginalia.translation: The celebate man is almost one of the gods. An ethereal man.

position.marginalia_text: Nihil eorum durum coelibi, qua[e] uxorio cuiq[ue] durissima.

marginalia.translation: None of those things, which are most troublesome for a married man, is troublesome for the celibate man.

position.marginalia_text: Vnum est maximi viri proprium, posse viuere minimo: et Sibi ipsi sufficientem, quàm minimè alijs egere.

marginalia.translation: There is one thing particular to the greatest man: being capable of living with less. He should be self-sufficient, rather than have need of others.

position.marginalia_text: De venere prudentissimè Guicciardinus, i[nfr]a, 163. Hippocratis aphorismus.

marginalia.translation: Guicciardini, most prudently regarding Venus. [See] below, pg. 163. The aphorism of Hippocrates.

position.marginalia_text: Miser homo, cui adhuc discenda è Libris virtus, aut Industria.

marginalia.translation: Miserable is the man for whom virtue and industriousness must be learned from books.

position.marginalia_text: Venus est maxima inimia solidi corporis, firmi animi, industrij status: abstinentia[e], studij, meditationis, vigilantia[e], Laboris: assuetudinis, patientia[e], Constantia[e]:
omnium deniq[ue] arduorum, ingentiumq[ue] operum. Facit semihomines, qui alioqui possent esse solidi viri.

marginalia.translation: Venus is the greatest enemy of the strong body, the stable mind, and the industrious attitude. She is the enemy of abstinence, study, contemplation, vigilance, work, habit, patience, constancy, and, finally, of all difficult and great tasks. She produces half-men who would otherwise be whole men.
